channel.title: RFID and NFC
channel.description:
Due to the increasing frequency that I've been locking the keys in my car, I've decided to make a device that unlocks the driver-side door when the keys are within about 2 meters. That way, I could never lock the keys in the car again. I'm just not sure how I would go about doing this. I know the basics (attach receiver to 12V, attach transmitter to key ring) but there are many different ways of accomplishing it. What would your suggestions be for going about this? I've also come up with a few constraints that should limit the implementation.
1. Both the receiver and transmitter should have minimal power consumption. 2. The signal shouldn't be hindered (greatly) by interference (like the chassis of the car). 3. The transmitter shouldn't go more than 2-3 meters.
Now, after the first implementation, I might make it more functional (by adding a switch for which doors to open), but for right now, one will do. So what are some things you guys can suggest?

item.title: RFID and NFC
item.dc:creator: @amy_webb1 amy_webb
item.description:
@amy_webb1 wrote:

I’ve got it! Tie a sting from your keys to your pants so if you walk of they go with you, but are still far away enough to fit into the transmition? My + car things aren’t good, but i shall learn!

Read full topic

item.title: RFID and NFC
item.dc:creator: @whattehp406 whattehp406
item.description:
@whattehp406 wrote:

CodeForFame has a good idea there, why don’t you just ductape the key to get in ( not to start) somewhere only you know?

Read full topic

item.title: RFID and NFC
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:33, topic:431404”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=534083.msg3909484#msg3909484 date=1328567773]

[quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=534083.msg3909394#msg3909394 date=1328562752]

[quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=534083.msg3909066#msg3909066 date=1328507694]

Just do what I do, make a copy of the key and put it in your wallet.

And then when your wallet goes missing, so does your car!
[/quote]If you have a modern car it will have a transponder. This way you can only get into your car, but not start it (using the spare key).

I don’t need to worry about starting it, because the transmitter will always be attached to the keyring.
[/quote]Read my initial post… How are you going to make this transmitter work with rolling codes? You’ll need to know how it works internally, then spend a few grand to get the equipment/software to actually program the car, etc. Furthermore, most of the documentation on how it works is not available to the general public, and is either expensive and/or requires a locksmith license. Doing these types of things are not financially viable, which is why there are these people called locksmiths.

If you did go the locksmith route, I’m sure you’d be pretty hard pressed to find a locksmith that will potentially risk their license (I’d have to look into the actual ‘rules’ they must abide by for the country you live in) for something so dumb. Even then, it will probably cost $100+ (it can be cheaper depending on the car, but $60-70 is really as cheap as you’ll get it) to get them to program it (if they’re not risking losing their license). So, you’d better be damn sure you have no bugs, and have a flawless system before you spend the money to have it programmed.

If you simply want to learn more about electronics and such, there are much better and cheaper ways to go about it.

What do you mean “rolling codes”? I’m not planning on programming anying inside the car. The only thing I’m doing is creating a device, splicing the wires that operate the doors to the device, and connecting the device to the 12v electrical output in the car.

EDIT: After researching rolling codes, I am still not worried about it.

First of all, I doubt there are more than 50 people in a 10 mile radius that know what a rolling code is, let alone create a device that could copy the signal, and transmit it.

Second, I don’t have a “fancy” car. There is nothing of value inside. Everything is stock. If they wanted to steal it, they wouldn’t need to go through such measures.

Third, if someone did manage to copy and replay the code, they would still need the key to start the car, which they could just as easily get by taking a rock and breaking the window.
[/quote]If you leave your keys in the car anyone can walk by and just steal the entire car. And if you’re not worried about that, then why not just disable the locks, or duct tape a key (without a transponder) onto the side of your car?

Also, I was assuming you were going to cleanly, and securely integrate this, rather than bootleg it; I figured you wanted to do it properly seeing you were trying to learn.

A better solution would to get a RFID ring or other piece of jewelry (they also have stickers, so you could put it on your phone/wallet). This way if you lock your keys in the car it’s not sitting there unlocked until you walk up to it.

As for the rolling codes, those are already in place, and they’re already being used. You can’t copy transponder keys and the like without the correct software and hardware, which is not cheap. Anyway, your solution wouldn’t be using them at all, which means it’s less secure, and someone would just need to transmit the correct frequency. But as you said, you’re not concerned with that.[/quote]

Now you’re catching on.

Read full topic

item.title: RFID and NFC
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:32, topic:431404”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=534083.msg3909394#msg3909394 date=1328562752]

[quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=534083.msg3909066#msg3909066 date=1328507694]

Just do what I do, make a copy of the key and put it in your wallet.

And then when your wallet goes missing, so does your car!
[/quote]If you have a modern car it will have a transponder. This way you can only get into your car, but not start it (using the spare key).

I don’t need to worry about starting it, because the transmitter will always be attached to the keyring.
[/quote]Read my initial post… How are you going to make this transmitter work with rolling codes? You’ll need to know how it works internally, then spend a few grand to get the equipment/software to actually program the car, etc. Furthermore, most of the documentation on how it works is not available to the general public, and is either expensive and/or requires a locksmith license. Doing these types of things are not financially viable, which is why there are these people called locksmiths.

If you did go the locksmith route, I’m sure you’d be pretty hard pressed to find a locksmith that will potentially risk their license (I’d have to look into the actual ‘rules’ they must abide by for the country you live in) for something so dumb. Even then, it will probably cost $100+ (it can be cheaper depending on the car, but $60-70 is really as cheap as you’ll get it) to get them to program it (if they’re not risking losing their license). So, you’d better be damn sure you have no bugs, and have a flawless system before you spend the money to have it programmed.

If you simply want to learn more about electronics and such, there are much better and cheaper ways to go about it.

What do you mean “rolling codes”? I’m not planning on programming anying inside the car. The only thing I’m doing is creating a device, splicing the wires that operate the doors to the device, and connecting the device to the 12v electrical output in the car.

EDIT: After researching rolling codes, I am still not worried about it.

First of all, I doubt there are more than 50 people in a 10 mile radius that know what a rolling code is, let alone create a device that could copy the signal, and transmit it.

Second, I don’t have a “fancy” car. There is nothing of value inside. Everything is stock. If they wanted to steal it, they wouldn’t need to go through such measures.

Third, if someone did manage to copy and replay the code, they would still need the key to start the car, which they could just as easily get by taking a rock and breaking the window.[/quote]If you leave your keys in the car anyone can walk by and just steal the entire car. And if you’re not worried about that, then why not just disable the locks, or duct tape a key (without a transponder) onto the side of your car?

Also, I was assuming you were going to cleanly, and securely integrate this, rather than bootleg it; I figured you wanted to do it properly seeing you were trying to learn.

A better solution would to get a RFID ring or other piece of jewelry (they also have stickers, so you could put it on your phone/wallet). This way if you lock your keys in the car it’s not sitting there unlocked until you walk up to it.

As for the rolling codes, those are already in place, and they’re already being used. You can’t copy transponder keys and the like without the correct software and hardware, which is not cheap. Anyway, your solution wouldn’t be using them at all, which means it’s less secure, and someone would just need to transmit the correct frequency. But as you said, you’re not concerned with that.

Read full topic

Even then, it will probably cost $100+ (it can be cheaper depending on the car, but $60-70 is really as cheap as you’ll get it) to get them to program it (if they’re not risking losing their license). So, you’d better be damn sure you have no bugs, and have a flawless system before you spend the money to have it programmed.

EDIT: After researching rolling codes, I am still not worried about it.

First of all, I doubt there are more than 50 people in a 10 mile radius that know what a rolling code is, let alone create a device that could copy the signal, and transmit it.

Second, I don’t have a “fancy” car. There is nothing of value inside. Everything is stock. If they wanted to steal it, they wouldn’t need to go through such measures.

Third, if someone did manage to copy and replay the code, they would still need the key to start the car, which they could just as easily get by taking a rock and breaking the window.

item.title: RFID and NFC
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

Good luck… Almost all of those type of things have rolling (hopping) codes.

You’d be better off attaching a spare set of keys. They make things specifically for it, some are gas caps (they have a combo on them), others are similar to this:

amazon.com

Kidde AccessPoint 001413 KeySafe Original Slimline Push Button Combination Permanent Key Lock Box, 2-Key, White - Cabinet Style Safes - Amazon.com

"SUPRA" SLIMLINE KEY SAFE Push button key pad (resettable) Stores spare keys for house or business Slimline design Permanent mount (includes 4 screws) Rustproof White Clamshell

I’d suggest putting a key that will only open the door.

For more suggestions or to get someone to implement these, contact a local locksmith.

Read full topic

item.title: RFID and NFC
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

SilentCJ:

How do you lock yourself in? Forgive me but I just got my first car, and I can’t get my head around how you would lock yourself out… I mean I’d have to manually lock the door from outside, then slip the keys through the sunroof or window to lock myself out

Usually what happens is I go in to grab something, put the keys on the passenger seat, grab what I went to look for, and lock the door with the switch on the door.

As for the “hacking”, I would use a signal frequency, or transmission packet that only I would know. Besides, if they really wanted to get in, they could just use a rock and break the window.

Read full topic
